nodes.title: Info
widgets_values:
# Example prompts

Describe this track in full detail - tell me the genre, tempo, and key, then dive into the instruments and describe the song structure.
___

Generate a structured lyric sheet from the input music.
___

Write a rich caption that blends the technical details (genre, BPM, key, chords, mix) with how the song feels emotionally and dynamically as it unfolds.
___
Which line directly precedes the chorus?

This track is a Latin‑American folk piece that fuses traditional Mexican corrido storytelling with a modern, protest‑song sensibility.  It sits squarely in the folk‑corrido sub‑genre, blending acoustic guitar‑driven folk textures with the narrative drive of a corrido and a spoken‑word protest monologue. The duration of the piece is 234.02 seconds.
Tempo & key – The song moves at a brisk ≈ 143 BPM and is rooted in G minor, giving it a somber yet resolute tonal centre.
Instrumentation & production – The arrangement is built around a warm, resonant acoustic guitar that carries the harmonic rhythm, a simple electric bass that underpins the low end, and a modest drum kit (kick, snare, hi‑hat) that provides a steady 4/4 pulse. The production is deliberately raw and lo‑fi: minimal processing, narrow stereo imaging, and a dry mix that places the vocals front‑and‑center, preserving the intimate, “live‑room” feel of a street‑corner performance.
Vocal characteristics – A male lead sings in Spanish with a clear, slightly nasal timbre, delivering the verses in a direct, narrative style. The vocal delivery is clean (no distortion or heavy effects) and emphasizes the lyrical content, reinforcing the track’s protest‑song ethos.
Lyrical themes – The lyrics paint a vivid portrait of Tijuana, celebrating its nightlife (“Tequila, sexo, marihuana”) while simultaneously voicing social critique. Refrains such as “Bienvenida a Tijuana” and “Bienvenida mi amor” recur throughout, anchoring the song’s hook. Later sections shift to a spoken‑word protest, enumerating demands for justice, freedom, and basic rights (“Nuestra lucha es por el respeto a nuestro derecho a gobernar…”, “Techo, tierra, trabajo, pan, salud, educación, independencia, democracia, libertad”). The juxtaposition of celebratory and protest verses creates a layered narrative of love, community, and resistance.
Structure & dynamics – The form is essentially verse‑driven, with each verse followed by a short instrumental break that lets the acoustic guitar and bass breathe. Mid‑song the arrangement opens into an extended spoken‑word segment, which functions as a bridge and a climax, heightening the track’s urgency before returning to the final refrain. Dynamic intensity rises gradually
